content.question: Consider a 90 percent confidence interval for a population proportion <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is a correct interpretation of the confidence level 90 percent?

choices.label: There is approximately a 90 percent chance that <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is contained in the interval.

There is approximately a 90 percent chance that a randomly selected proportion <math alttext="p hat" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> will be contained in the interval.

Approximately 90 percent of all possible sample proportions <math alttext="p hat" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> will be contained in the interval.

In repeated samplings with the same sample size, approximately 90 percent of the intervals created will capture the population proportion <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

In repeated samplings with the same sample size, approximately 90 percent of the intervals created will capture the sample proportion <math alttext="p hat" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: In repeated samplings with the same sample size, approximately 90 percent of the intervals created will capture the population proportion <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
